Pro Log: First week chaos at the Vuelta, Sepp Kuss becomes first American in a decade to lead a Grand Tour, Lennard Kämna completes Grand Tour set and Tour of Britain begins

Welcome back to another edition of Pro Log. It’s a rest day at the Vuelta a España and Sepp Kuss (Jumbo-Visma) wears the maillot rojo by 43 seconds ahead of Marc Soler (UAE Team Emirates) and 1:02 over Lenny Martinez (Groupama-FDJ).

The Tour of Britain is also underway and Olav Kooij (Jumbo-Visma) has been having a brilliant time, winning two stages from two so far and leading the general classification ahead of teammate Wout van Aert.

First week chaos at the Vuelta a España

You could probably have scripted it, but no one would’ve believed you. The first week at the Vuelta a España has been… interesting to see the least. Issues arose on the first stage – a team time trial won by DSM-Firmenich in Barcelona – when a later start combined with rain plunged the Vuelta into darkness. Defending champion Remco Evenepoel (Soudal-QuickStep) said they ‘couldn’t see anything’ and Lotto-Dstny’s Thomas De Gendt revealed to CPA (Cyclistes Professionnels Associés – the riders’ union) president Adam Hansen that riders had to take a 6km trip through heavy traffic and without lights back to the team buses.

The heavy rain continued on Stage 2. Initially, organisers planned to take GC times from the summit of the Category 3 ascent to Montjuic, around 4km from the finish line to essentially neutralise a potentially dangerous descent. But rider protests prevailed and the marker for GC times was moved to 9km to go, cutting out the final climb completely for GC timings. But how exactly were commissaires taking times at this section? By asking for videos on fans’ phones to see when the riders passed through. Now that’s the kind of professionalism you expect from a longstanding WorldTour race.

Confusión para conocer el orden de paso en el punto bonificado. El comisario de carrera pregunta a aficionados si han grabado la llegada de los ciclistas. #LaVuelta23 pic.twitter.com/CMca3ASPJy

— Raúl Banqueri (@raulbanqueri) August 27, 2023

To make it even worse, tacks had also been thrown into the road on Stage 2. Juan Ayuso (UAE Team Emirates) was rightfully frustrated, saying: ‘I want to say thank you to this person for being an idiot and I wish the same thing happens to him what he wished for us. I wish him worse.’

It doesn’t end there. The National Police Corps in Spain arrested four people in connection with a plan to pour 400 litres of oil onto the peloton from a bridge during Stage 3. At that day’s finish in Andorra, Remco Evenepoel won ahead of Jumbo-Visma’s Jonas Vingegaard and very briefly celebrated before crashing into the press officer of the Andorran police force. His head was left covered in blood, which was then washed away to thankfully reveal a much smaller cut on his forehead. All of this, plus the mud and gravel that forced organisers to take timings from 50m outside the 2km mark on Stage 9 and rest day flights being redirected due to bad weather, and you can begin to see how chaotic this year’s Vuelta has been so far. Hopefully there won’t be too much disturbance in the second week…

GC Kuss

A Jumbo-Visma rider in the red jersey and it’s not Primož Roglič or Jonas Vingegaard? Yes, superdomestique Sepp Kuss has been making headlines for his stint atop the general classification as he became the first American in a decade to wear the leader’s jersey at a Grand Tour. The last was Chris Horner in 2013, when he won it aged 41.

Kuss got himself in a big breakaway and rode away from his rivals to win on Stage 6, high-fiving fans across the line, and rode his way into red on Stage 8. It’s a great achievement for a man who is always in the service of others. Kuss has taken part in all three Grand Tours this year and played an essential part in Roglič and Vingegaard winning the Giro d’Italia and Tour de France respectively.

Lennard Kämna completes Grand Tour set

Speaking of all three Grand Tours, Lennard Kämna (Bora-Hansgohe) became the latest rider to complete the ‘Grand Tour triple’ at just 26 years old with his solo victory on Stage 9 at the Vuelta. The same day GC times were taken from the very specific 50m from the 2km to go point due to mud and gravel on the road, he had to fight all the way to the line.

He completes an impressive collection of Grand Tour wins following his victory on Mount Etna at the 2022 Giro d’Italia and hilly Stage 16 at the 2020 Tour de France. As teammate Jai Hindley would say, he’s certainly teaching lessons in shreducation.

Tour of Britain begins in Manchester

Yes, a race only went and passed by my window as things kicked off in Manchester for Stage 1 of the Tour of Britain. It was a lovely experience to see riders race past my local roads, where I don’t go out training on a bike but walk to Starbucks and Waterstones instead. Olav Kooij has won the first two stages so far and teammate/leadout man Wout van Aert sits right behind him in second with the same time on GC.

See you next week.
